topics.title: Verb Conjugation
topics.explanation: In German, verbs change their form depending on the subject (pronoun). This is called conjugation. For regular verbs in the present tense, you typically remove the -en ending and add a new ending.

practice_questions.question: Which is the correct form of 'sein' (to be) for 'ich'?
Which is the correct form of 'haben' (to have) for 'du'?
Which is the correct form of 'spielen' (to play) for 'er'?

topics.title: Basic Sentence Structure
topics.explanation: In a simple German statement, the verb is always in the second position. The subject is often in the first position, but another element can be placed first for emphasis, in which case the subject moves after the verb.

practice_questions.question: Which sentence has the correct word order?
Rearrange the words to form a correct sentence: 'morgen / wir / ins Kino / gehen'

topics.title: Nominative Case
topics.explanation: The nominative case is used for the subject of a sentence—the person or thing performing the action. The articles 'der', 'die', 'das' are in their basic, nominative form.

practice_questions.question: Which pronoun is in the nominative case in the sentence: 'Er liest ein Buch.'?
